_accidents.CF_Other: Attempted theft by individual for drug production
_accidents.CI_OtherType: Increase police patrol and employees to monitor facility

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Facility accidental release and emergency response policy. The management and employees of Effingham Clay Service Company are committed to prevention of accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia. If any accidental release should occur. The facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, Local Emergency planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.
2.    The stationary source and the regulated substances handled. The primary activity at the facility which is located at 310 West North Water Street, Bethany  Illinois is the storage and blending of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling systems consists of one AA? 30,000gallon and one 18.000gallon storage tanks, loading risers, and associated plumbing and nurse tanks.
3.    The accidental release prevention program. This facility complies withy EPAAA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of AA?Safety requirements for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, K-61.1, published by the American National Standards Institute Inc.  As adopted by State regulations and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). 29 CFR 1910.111, AA?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous AmmoniaAA?. Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.
4.    Five year accident history. We had an accidental release of approx 72 pounds of anhydrous on 10/18/2007 as a result of an attempted theft of anhydrous for drug production. The local fire department responded and turned the valve off that was leaking a small amount of product. The person that was stealing the product was apparently injured in the face by the product and ended u

p at the hospital in Decatur. No one else or any member of the public was injured and no property damage resulted from the leak.
5.    The Emergency Response Program. The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29CFR 1910.38 and have provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right to know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA)
6.    Planned changes to improve safety. Safety improvement is an on going process at the facility, Periodic evaluations are performed to access the maintenance of safe conditions, There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
